When people get bad news, they hate the messenger. Therefore, it was very hard for the union representative to tell all of these people that the easy money was about to stop. That is not the way to advance as a union representative. So my friend closed his plant and moved the work to Utah among a community of believing Mormons. Well, the Mormons aren‚Äôt into workers‚Äô compensation fraud‚Äîat least they aren‚Äôt in my friend‚Äôs plant. And guess what his workers‚Äô compensation expense is today? It‚Äôs 2 percent of payroll. This sort of tragedy is caused by letting the slop run. You must stop slop early. It‚Äôs very hard to stop slop and moral failure if you let it run for a while. [Charlie describes his notion of deprival-super¬≠reaction syndrome as it relates to gambling and the New Coke debacle of the mid-1980s.] Of course, as I said before, there is one big consideration that needs huge and special attention as part of any use of techniques deliberately harnessing elementary psychological forces, and that is that once you know how to do it, there are real moral limits regarding how much you should do it. Not all of what you know how to do should you use to manipulate people. Also, if you‚Äôre willing to transcend the moral limits and the person you‚Äôre trying to manipulate realizes what you‚Äôre doing because he also understands the psychology, he‚Äôll hate you. There is wonderfully persuasive evidence of this effect taken from labor relations, some in Israel. So not only are there moral objections, but there are also practical objections‚Äîbig ones in some cases. Audience question: How do you incorporate psychology in your investment decisions? I think it would be more than just picking products that will appeal to everybody, like Coke. After all, there are a lot of smart people out there who obviously think just the way you showed us today. So are you looking for failure in the thinking of other investors when you go about picking successful companies? What makes investment hard, as I said at USC, is that it‚Äôs easy to see that some companies have better businesses than others. But the price of the stock goes up so high that all of a sudden, the question of which stock is the best to buy gets quite difficult. We‚Äôve never eliminated the difficulty of that problem. And 98 percent of the time, our attitude toward the market is that we‚Äôre agnostics. We don‚Äôt know. Is GM valued properly vis-√†-vis Ford? We don‚Äôt know. We‚Äôre always looking for something where we think we have an insight that gives us a big statistical advantage. Sometimes it comes from psychology, but often it comes from something else. And we only find a few, maybe one or two a year. We have no system for having automatic good judgment on all investment decisions that can be made. Ours is a totally different system. We just look for no-brainer decisions. As Buffett and I say over and over again, we don‚Äôt leap 7-foot fences. Instead, we look for 1-foot fences with big rewards on the other side. So we‚Äôve succeeded by making the world easy for ourselves, not by solving hard problems. Based on statistical analysis and insight? Well, certainly when we do make a decision, we think that we have an insight advantage. And it‚Äôs true that some of the insight is statistical in nature. However, again, we find only a few of those. It doesn‚Äôt help us merely for favorable odds to exist. They have to be in a place where we can recognize them. So it takes a mispriced opportunity that we‚Äôre smart enough to recognize. And that combination doesn‚Äôt occur often. But it doesn‚Äôt have to. If you wait for the big opportunity and have the courage and vigor to grasp it firmly when it arrives, how many do you need? For example, take the top 10 business investments Berkshire Hathaway‚Äôs ever made. We would be very rich if we‚Äôd never done anything else‚Äîin two lifetimes. So, once again, we don‚Äôt have any system for giving you perfect investment judgment on all subjects at all times. That would be ridiculous. I‚Äôm just trying to give you a method you can use to sift reality to obtain an occasional opportunity for rational reaction. If you take that method into something as competitive as common stock picking, you‚Äôre competing with many brilliant people. So even with our method, we only get a few opportunities. Fortunately, that happens to be enough. Have you been successful in creating an atmosphere where people below you can do the same things you‚Äôre talking about doing yourself? For example, you talked about the tendency toward commitment and consistency ‚Ä¶ Mostly about the terrible mistakes it causes you to make. How have you created an atmosphere comfortable enough for people to abandon that tendency and admit that they‚Äôve made a mistake? For example, someone here earlier this year from Intel talked about problems that occurred with their Pentium chip. One of the most difficult things for them to do was to realize they‚Äôd been going about it the wrong way and turn course. And it‚Äôs very difficult to do that in a complex structure. How do you foster that? Intel and its ilk create a coherent culture where teams solve difficult problems on the cutting edge of science. That‚Äôs radically different from Berkshire Hathaway. Berkshire is a holding company. We‚Äôve decentralized all the power, except for natural headquarters-type capital allocation. By and large, we‚Äôve chosen people we admire enormously to have the power beneath us. It‚Äôs easy for us to get along with them, on average, because we love and admire them. And they create the culture for whatever invention and reality recognition is going on in their businesses. And included in that reality recognition is the recognition that previous conclusions were incorrect. But we‚Äôre a totally different kind of company. It‚Äôs not at all clear to me that Warren or I would be that good at doing what Andy Grove42 does. We don‚Äôt have special competence in that field. We are fairly good at relating to brilliant people we love. But we have defects. For example, some regard me as absentminded and opinionated. I might be a mess at Intel. However, both Warren and I are very good at changing our prior conclusions. We work at developing that facility because without it, disaster often comes. Would you talk a little bit about your seeming predilection away from investing in high-technology stocks, on your own part and the part of Berkshire Hathaway? One of the things I‚Äôve found eye-opening and a little surprising is how the difficulties of running a low-tech business and those of running a high-tech business aren‚Äôt all that different. They‚Äôre all hard. But why should it be easy to get rich? In a competitive world, shouldn‚Äôt it be impossible for there to be an easy way for everybody to get rich? Of course they‚Äôre all hard. The reason we‚Äôre not in high-tech businesses is that we have a special lack of aptitude in that area. And yes‚Äîa low-tech business can be plenty hard. Just try to open a restaurant and make it succeed. You seem to be suggesting that there‚Äôs special aptitude required in high-tech businesses‚Äîthat they‚Äôre harder. But aren‚Äôt they equally difficult? The advantage of low-tech stuff for us is that we think we understand it fairly well. The other stuff we don‚Äôt. And we‚Äôd rather deal with what we understand. Why should we want to play a competitive game in a field where we have no advantage‚Äîmaybe a disadvantage‚Äîinstead of in a field where we have a clear advantage? Each of you will have to figure out where your talents lie. And you‚Äôll have to use your advantages. But if you try to succeed in what you‚Äôre worst at, you‚Äôre going to have a very lousy career. I can almost guarantee it. To do otherwise, you‚Äôd have to buy a winning lottery ticket or get very lucky somewhere else. Warren Buffett has said that the investment Berkshire made in an airline was a good example of what not to do. What chain of thinking led to that wrong decision? We were not buying stock in USAir on the theory that the common shareholders were certain to prosper, because the history of the airline business in terms of taking care of shareholders has been terrible. It was a preferred stock with a mandatory redemption. In effect, we were loaning money to USAir, and we had this equity kicker. We weren‚Äôt guessing whether it would be a great place for the shareholders. We were guessing whether it would remain prosperous enough to pay off a credit instrument, carrying a fixed dividend and a mandatory redemption. And we guessed that the business would not get so bad that we‚Äôd have a credit threat for which we were not being adequately compensated by the high rate we were getting. As it happened, USAir went right to the brink of going broke. It was hanging by a thread for several months. It‚Äôs since come back. And we‚Äôll probably get all our money back plus the whole coupon. But it was a mistake. [Editor‚Äôs note: Berkshire did indeed come out whole on its USAir investment.] I don‚Äôt want you to think we have any way of learning or behaving so you won‚Äôt make a lot of mistakes. I‚Äôm just saying that you can learn to make fewer mistakes than other people‚Äîand how to fix your mistakes faster when you do make them. But there‚Äôs no way that you can live an adequate life without making many mistakes. Part of what you must learn is how to handle mistakes and new facts that change the odds. Life, in part, is like a poker game, wherein you have to learn to quit sometimes when holding a much-loved hand. In fact, one trick in life is to get so you can handle mistakes. Failure to handle psychological denial is a common way for people to go broke. You‚Äôve made an enormous commitment to something. You‚Äôve poured effort and money in. And the more you put in, the more the whole consistency principle makes you think, ‚ÄúNow it has to work. If I put in just a little more, then it‚Äôll work.‚Äù And deprival-super¬≠reaction syndrome also comes in: You‚Äôre going to lose the whole thing if you don‚Äôt put in a little more. People go broke that way because they can‚Äôt stop, rethink, and say, ‚ÄúI can afford to write this one off and live to fight again. I don‚Äôt have to pursue this thing as an obsession, in a way that will break me.‚Äù Could you talk about the thoughts that went into your decision to swap your Capital Cities stock for Disney rather than taking cash? In the media, it was reported that you mentioned thinking about taking the cash. Disney‚Äôs a perfectly marvelous company, but it‚Äôs also very high-priced. Part of what it does is make ordinary movies, which is not a business that attracts me at all. However, part of what Disney has is better than a great gold mine. I mean, those videocassettes ‚Ä¶ Disney is an amazing example of autocatalysis.43 They had all those movies in the can. They owned the copyright. And just as Coke could prosper when refrigeration came, when the videocassette was invented, Disney didn‚Äôt have to invent anything or do anything except take the thing out of the can and stick it on the cassette. And every parent and grandparent wanted his descendants to sit around and watch that stuff at home on videocassette. So Disney got this enormous tailwind from life. And it was billions of dollars‚Äô worth of tailwind. Obviously, that‚Äôs a marvelous model if you can find it. You don‚Äôt have to invent anything. All you have to do is to sit there while the world carries you forward. Disney‚Äôs done a lot of new things right. Don‚Äôt misunderstand me. But a lot of what happened to Disney was like what a friend of mine said about an ignorant fraternity brother of his who succeeded in life: ‚ÄúHe was a duck sitting on a pond, and they raised the level of the pond.‚Äù Eisner and Wells were brilliant in how they ran Disney. But the huge tailwind from videocassette sales on all of the old stuff that was there when they came in‚Äîthat was just an automatic break for the new management. To be fair, they have been brilliant about creating new stuff, like Pocahontas and The Lion King, to catch the same tailwind. But by the time it‚Äôs done, The Lion King alone is going to do plural billions. And by the way, when I say ‚Äúwhen it‚Äôs done,‚Äù I mean 50 years from now or something. But plural billions‚Äîfrom one movie? Could you talk about why you left the law? I had a huge family. Nancy and I supported eight children. And I didn‚Äôt realize that the law was going to get as prosperous as it suddenly got. The big money came into law shortly after I left it. By 1962, I was mostly out, and I was totally out by 1965. So that was a long time ago. Also, I preferred making the decisions and gambling my own money. I usually thought I knew better than the client anyway. So why should I have to do it his way? So partly it was having an opinionated personality. And partly it was a desire to get resources permitting independence. Also, the bulk of my clients were terrific, but there were one or two I didn‚Äôt enjoy. Plus, I like the independence of a capitalist. And I‚Äôd always had sort of a gambling personality. I like figuring things out and making bets. So I simply did what came naturally. Do you ever gamble Las Vegas‚Äì¬≠style? I won‚Äôt bet $100 against house odds between now and the grave. I don‚Äôt do that. Why should I? I will gamble recreationally with my pals. And I‚Äôll occasionally play a much better bridge player, like Bob Hamman, who might be the best card player in the world. But I know I‚Äôm paying for the fun of playing with him. That‚Äôs recreational. As for gambling with simple mechanical house odds against me, why in the world would I ever want to do that, particularly given how I detest the manipulative culture of legalized gambling? I don‚Äôt like legalized gambling. And I‚Äôm not comfortable in Las Vegas, even though it does now include a higher percentage of wholesome family recreation. I don‚Äôt like to be with many of the types who hang around card parlors and so forth. On the other hand, I do like the manly art of wagering, so to speak. And I like light social gambling among friends. But I do not like the professional gambling milieu. Could you say something about how the mutual fund and money management business has changed since you got into it, and the growth of capital markets? Actually, I didn‚Äôt really get into it. I had a little private partnership for 14 years, up until a little over 20 years ago. However, I never had enough money from other people to amount to a hill of beans‚Äîat least by current investment management standards. So I‚Äôve never really been part of the mutual fund business. But the money management business has been one of the great growth businesses in the recent history of the United States. It‚Äôs created many affluent professionals and multi¬≠millionaires. It‚Äôs been a perfect gold mine for people who got in it early. The growth of pension funds, the value of American corporations, and the world‚Äôs wealth have created a fabulous profession for many and carried lots of them up to affluence. And we deal with them in a variety of ways. However, we haven‚Äôt been part of it for many years. We‚Äôve basically invested our own money for a long, long time. Do you expect this bull run to continue? Well, I‚Äôd be amazed if the capitalized value of all American business weren‚Äôt considerably higher 25 years from now. And if people continue to trade with one another and shuffle these pieces of paper around, then money management may continue to be a marvelous business for the managers. But except for what might be called our own money, we‚Äôre really not in it. I was interested in the evolution of your investment strategy from when you first began using the Ben Graham model to the Berkshire Hathaway model. Would you recommend that model to a beginning investor‚Äîi.e., dumping most of it or all of it into one opportunity we think is a great one and leaving it there for decades? Or is that strategy really for a more mature investor? Each person has to play the game given his own marginal utility considerations and in a way that takes into account his own psychology. If losses are going to make you miserable‚Äîand some losses are inevitable‚Äîyou might be wise to utilize a very conservative pattern of investment and saving all your life. So you have to adapt your strategy to your own nature and your own talents. I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a one-size-fits-all investment strategy that I can give you. Mine works for me. But in part, that‚Äôs because I‚Äôm good at taking losses. I can take ‚Äôem psychologically. And, besides, I have very few. The combination works fine. You and Buffett have said that Berkshire‚Äôs stock is overvalued and you wouldn‚Äôt recommend buying it. We didn‚Äôt say we thought it was overvalued. We just said that we wouldn‚Äôt buy it or recommend that our friends buy it at the prices then prevailing. But that just related to Berkshire‚Äôs intrinsic value as it was at that time. If I had the money, I would buy it‚Äîbecause you‚Äôve been saying that your returns will go down for 20 years ‚Ä¶ Well, I hope that your optimism is justified. But I do not change my opinion. After all, today we‚Äôre in uncharted territory. I sometimes tell my friends, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing the best I can. But I‚Äôve never grown old before. I‚Äôm doing it for the first time, and I‚Äôm not sure that I‚Äôll do it right.‚Äù Warren and I have never been in this kind of territory‚Äîwith high valuations and a huge amount of capital. We‚Äôve never done it before. So we‚Äôre learning. Everything you and Buffett say seems logical. But it sounds like exactly the same language that Ben Graham was using 30 years ago when he was saying the stock market was overvalued, when it was at 900. Oh, I don‚Äôt think that we share that with him. Graham, great though he was as a man, had a screw loose as he tried to predict outcomes for the stock market as a whole. In contrast, Warren and I are almost always agnostic about the market. On the other hand, we have said that common stocks generally have generated returns of 10 to 11 percent after inflation for many years and that those returns can‚Äôt continue for a very long period. And they can‚Äôt. It‚Äôs simply impossible. The wealth of the world will compound at no such rate. Whatever experience Stanford has had in its portfolio for the last 15 years, its future experience is virtually certain to be worse. It may still be okay. But it‚Äôs been a hog-heaven period for investors over the last 15 years. Bonanza effects of such scale can‚Äôt last forever. Berkshire‚Äôs annual report got a lot of press for being pessimistic and for expressing concern about the shrinking pool of opportunities as the company gets bigger and bigger. Where does that leave you 10 years from now? We‚Äôve said over and over that our future rate of compounding our shareholders‚Äô wealth is going to go down compared to our past, and that our size will be an anchor dragging on performance. And we‚Äôve said over and over again that this is not an opinion but a promise. However, let‚Äôs suppose that we were able to compound our present book value at 15 percent per annum from this point. That would not be so bad and would work out okay for our long-term shareholder. I‚Äôm just saying that we could afford to slow down some, as we surely will, and still do okay for the long-term shareholder. By the way, I‚Äôm not promising that we will compound our present book value at 15 percent per annum. You talked about how important it was not to have an extreme ideology. What responsibility, if any, do you think the business and legal communities have for helping inner-city areas, spreading the wealth and so on? I‚Äôm all for fixing social problems. I‚Äôm all for being generous to the less fortunate. And I‚Äôm all for doing things where, based on a slight preponderance of the evidence, you guess that it‚Äôs likely to do more good than harm. What I‚Äôm against is being very confident and feeling that you know, for sure, that your particular intervention will do more good than harm, given that you‚Äôre dealing with highly complex systems wherein everything is interacting with everything else. So just make sure that what you‚Äôre doing ‚Ä¶ You can‚Äôt make sure. That‚Äôs my point. On the other hand, I did recently reverse the conclusions of two sets of engineers. How did I have enough confidence in such a complicated field to do that? Well, you might think, ‚ÄúOh, this guy is just an egomaniac who‚Äôs made some money and thinks he knows everything.‚Äù Well, I may be an egomaniac, but I don‚Äôt think I know everything. But I saw huge reasons in the circumstances for bias in each set of engineers as each recommended a course of action very advantageous to itself. And what each was saying was so consonant with a natural bias that it made me distrust it. Also, perhaps I knew enough engineering to know that what they were saying didn‚Äôt make sense. Finally, I found a third engineer who recommended a solution I approved. And thereafter, the second engineer came to me and said, ‚ÄúCharlie, why didn‚Äôt I think of that?‚Äù Which is to his credit. It was a much better solution, both safer and cheaper. You must have the confidence to override people with more credentials than you whose cognition is impaired by incentive-caused bias or some similar psychological force that is obviously present. But there are also cases where you have to recognize that you have no wisdom to add and that your best course is to trust some expert. In effect, you‚Äôve got to know what you know and what you don‚Äôt know. What could possibly be more useful in life than that? You discussed Coke‚Äôs mistake. Do you have any thoughts about where Apple44 went wrong? Let me give you a very good answer‚Äîone I‚Äôm copying from Jack Welch, the CEO of General Electric. He has a PhD in engineering. He‚Äôs a star businessman. He‚Äôs a marvelous guy. And recently, in Warren‚Äôs presence, someone asked him, ‚ÄúJack, what did Apple do wrong?‚Äù His answer? ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have any special competence that would enable me to answer that question.‚Äù And I‚Äôll give you the very same answer. That‚Äôs not a field in which I‚Äôm capable of giving you any special insight. On the other hand, in copying Jack Welch, I am trying to teach you something. When you don‚Äôt know and you don‚Äôt have any special competence, don‚Äôt be afraid to say so. There‚Äôs another type of person I compare to an example from biology: When a bee finds nectar, it comes back and does a little dance that tells the rest of the hive, as a matter of genetic programming, which direction to go and how far. So about 40 or 50 years ago, some clever scientist stuck the nectar straight up. Well, the nectar‚Äôs never straight up in the ordinary life of a bee. The nectar‚Äôs out. So the bee finds the nectar and returns to the hive. But it doesn‚Äôt have the genetic programming to do a dance that says straight up. So what does it do? Well, if it were like Jack Welch, it would just sit there. But what it actually does is to dance this incoherent dance that gums things up. A lot of people are like that bee. They attempt to answer a question like that. And that is a huge mistake. Nobody expects you to know everything about everything. I try to get rid of people who always confidently answer questions about which they don‚Äôt have any real knowledge. To me, they‚Äôre like the bee dancing its incoherent dance. They‚Äôre just screwing up the hive. As someone who‚Äôs been in legal practice and business, how did you incorporate, or did you incorporate, these models into your legal practice? And how did it work? I suspect many of us have seen law firms that don‚Äôt appear to adhere to these kinds of models. Well, the models are there. But just as there are perverse incentives in academia, there are perverse incentives in law firms. In fact, in some respects, at the law firms, it‚Äôs much worse. Here‚Äôs another model from law practice: When I was very young, my father practiced law. One of his best friends, Grant McFayden, Omaha‚Äôs Pioneer Ford dealer, was a client. He was a perfectly marvelous man, a self-made Irishman who‚Äôd run away uneducated from a farm as a youth because his father beat him. So he made his own way in the world. He was a brilliant man of enormous charm and integrity‚Äîjust a wonderful, wonderful man. In contrast, my father had another client who was a blowhard, an overreaching, unfair, pompous, difficult man. And I must have been 14 years old or thereabouts when I asked, ‚ÄúDad, why do you do so much work for Mr. X, this overreaching blowhard, instead of working more for wonderful men like Grant McFayden?‚Äù My father said, ‚ÄúGrant McFayden treats his employees right, his customers right, and his problems right. And if he gets involved with a psychotic, he quickly walks over to where the psychotic is and works out an exit as fast as he can. Therefore, Grant McFayden doesn‚Äôt have enough remunerative law business to keep you in Coca-Cola. But Mr. X is a walking minefield of wonderful legal business.‚Äù This case demonstrates one of the troubles with practicing law. To a considerable extent, you‚Äôre going to be dealing with grossly defective people. They create an enormous amount of the remunerative law business. And even when your own client is a paragon of virtue, you‚Äôll often be dealing with gross defectives on the other side or even on the bench. That‚Äôs partly what drove me out of the profession. The rest was my own greed, but my success in serving greed partly allowed me to make easier the process of being honorable and sensible. Like Ben Franklin observed, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard for an empty sack to stand upright.‚Äù I‚Äôd argue that my father‚Äôs model when I asked him about the two clients was totally correct didaction. He taught me the right lesson. The lesson? As you go through life, sell your services once in a while to an unreasonable blowhard if that‚Äôs what you must do to feed your family. But run your own life like Grant McFayden. That was a great lesson. And he taught it in a very clever way‚Äîbecause instead of just pounding it in, he told it to me in a way that required a slight mental reach. I had to make the reach myself in order to get the idea that I should behave like Grant McFayden. And because I had to reach for it, he figured I‚Äôd hold it better. And, indeed, I‚Äôve held it all the way through until today, through all of these decades. That‚Äôs a very clever teaching method. There, again, we‚Äôre talking about elementary psychology. It‚Äôs elementary literature. Good literature makes the reader reach a little for understanding. Then it works better. You hold it better. It‚Äôs the commitment and consistency tendency. If you‚Äôve reached for it, the idea‚Äôs pounded in better. As a lawyer or executive, you‚Äôll want to teach somebody what my father taught me, or maybe you‚Äôll want to teach them something else. And you can use lessons like this. Isn‚Äôt that a great way to teach a child? My father used indirection on purpose. And look at how powerfully it worked‚Äîlike Captain Cook‚Äôs wise use of psychology. I‚Äôve been trying to imitate Grant McFayden ever since, for all my life. I may have had a few lapses. But at least I‚Äôve been trying. At the end of your article in OID, you mentioned that only a select few investment managers actually add value. Since you‚Äôre speaking to an audience of future lawyers, what would you encourage us to do in order to be able to add value in our profession? To the extent you become a person who thinks correctly, you can add great value. To the extent you‚Äôve learned it so well that you have enough confidence to intervene where it takes a little courage, you can add great value. And to the extent that you can prevent or stop some asininity that would otherwise destroy your firm, your client, or something that you care about, you can add great value. There are constructive tricks you can use. For example, one reason why my old classmate Joe Flom of Skadden, Arps has been such a successful lawyer is that he‚Äôs very good at dreaming up little vivid examples that serve to pound the point home in a way that really works. It‚Äôs enormously helpful when you‚Äôre serving clients or otherwise trying to persuade someone in a good cause to come up with a little humorous example. The ability to do that is a knack. So you could argue that the Joe Floms of the world are almost born with a gift. But he‚Äôs honed the gift. And to one degree or another, all of you were born with the gift, and you can hone it too. Occasionally, you get into borderline stuff. For instance, suppose you‚Äôve got a client who really wants to commit tax fraud. If he doesn‚Äôt push the tax law way beyond the line, he can‚Äôt stand it. He can‚Äôt shave in the morning if he thinks there‚Äôs been any cheating he could get by with that he hasn‚Äôt done. And there are people like that. They just feel they aren‚Äôt living aggressively enough. You can approach that situation in either of two ways: You can say, ‚ÄúI just won‚Äôt work for him,‚Äù and duck it. Or you can say, ‚ÄúWell, the circumstances of my life require that I work for him. And what I‚Äôm doing for him doesn‚Äôt involve my cheating. Therefore, I‚Äôll do it.‚Äù And if you see he wants to do something really stupid, it probably won‚Äôt work to tell him, ‚ÄúWhat you‚Äôre doing is bad. I have better morals than you.‚Äù That offends him. You‚Äôre young. He‚Äôs old. Therefore, instead of being persuaded, he‚Äôs more likely to react with ‚ÄúWho in the hell are you to establish the moral code of the whole world?‚Äù But instead, you can say to him, ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt do that without three other people beneath you knowing about it. Therefore, you‚Äôre making yourself subject to blackmail. You‚Äôre risking your reputation. You‚Äôre risking your family, your money,‚Äù etc. That is likely to work. And you‚Äôre telling him something that‚Äôs true. Do you want to spend a lot of time working for people where you have to use methods like that to get them to behave well? I think the answer is no. But if you‚Äôre hooked with it, appealing to his interest is likely to work better as a matter of human persuasion than appealing to anything else. That, again, is a powerful psychological principle with deep biological roots. I saw that psychological principle totally blown at Salomon. Salomon‚Äôs general counsel knew that the CEO, [John] Gutfreund,45 should have promptly told the federal authorities all about Salomon‚Äôs trading improprieties, in which Gutfreund didn‚Äôt participate and which he hadn‚Äôt caused. And the general counsel urged Gutfreund to do it. He told Gutfreund, in effect, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre probably not legally required to do that, but it‚Äôs the right thing to do. You really should.‚Äù But it didn‚Äôt work. The task was easy to put off because it was unpleasant. So that‚Äôs what Gutfreund did‚Äîhe put it off. The general counsel had very little constituency within Salomon except for the CEO. If the CEO went down, the general counsel was going down with him. Therefore, his whole career was on the line. So to save his career, he needed to talk the dilatory CEO into doing the right thing. It would‚Äôve been child‚Äôs play to get that job done right. All the general counsel had to do was to tell his boss, ‚ÄúJohn, this situation could ruin your life. You could lose your wealth. You could lose your reputation.‚Äù And it would have worked. CEOs don‚Äôt like the idea of being ruined, disgraced, and fired. The ex-general counsel of Salomon is brilliant and generous, and he had the right idea. However, he lost his job because he didn‚Äôt apply a little elementary psychology. He failed to recognize that what works best in most cases is to appeal to a man‚Äôs interest. But you don‚Äôt have to get similarly lousy results when you face similar situations. Just remember what happened to Gutfreund and his general counsel. The right lessons are easily learned if you‚Äôll work at it. And if you do learn them, you can be especially useful at crucial moments when others fail. And to the extent that you do become wise, diligent, objective, and especially able to persuade in a good cause, then you‚Äôre adding value. Would you discuss how the threat of litigation‚Äîshareholder lawsuits and so forth‚Äîand legal complexity in general have affected decision-making in big business? Well, every big business screams about its legal costs, screams about the amount of regulation, screams about the complexity of its life, screams about the plaintiffs‚Äô bar, particularly the class-action plaintiffs‚Äô bar. So there‚Äôs an absolute catechism on that where you could just copy the screams from one corporation to another and you‚Äôd hardly have to change a word. But what causes the screams has, so far, been a godsend for the law firms. The big law firms have had a long updraft. And they now tend to kind of cluck like an undertaker in a plague. An undertaker, of course, would look very unseemly if he were jumping up and down and playing his fiddle during the plague. So law firm partners say, ‚ÄúOh, isn‚Äôt it sad‚Äîall this complexity, all this litigation, all this unfairness.‚Äù But, really, they‚Äôre somewhat schizophrenic on the subject because it‚Äôs been very good for them. Some recent California initiatives created some interesting conduct. Part of the defense bar lobbied quietly against certain propositions and, effectively, against their clients because they didn‚Äôt want their clients to catch ‚Äôem in the process. And the reason they did so was because it became harder for plaintiffs to bring cases. If you make a living fighting overreaching and it keeps your children in school and somebody proposes a system that eliminates it‚Äîwell, that‚Äôs an adult experience and an adult choice that you have to make. So big corporations adapt. They have more litigation. They have to have a bigger legal department. They scream about what they don‚Äôt like. But they adapt. But hasn‚Äôt that legal complexity consumed a lot more of companies‚Äô resources over the last few decades? The answer is yes. There‚Äôs hardly a corporation in America that isn‚Äôt spending more on lawsuits and on compliance with various regulations than it was 20 years ago. And yes, some of the new regulation is stupid and foolish. And some was damn well necessary. And it will ever be thus, albeit with some ebb and flow. But have you seen or experienced any change in decision-making at corporations in their being less likely to take on riskier investments for fear of failure or liability? The only place I saw‚Äîwith another friend, not Warren‚Äîwas when I was part owner of the biggest shareholder in a company that invented a better policeman‚Äôs helmet. It was made of Kevlar or something of that sort. They brought it to us and wanted us to manufacture it. As a matter of ideology, we‚Äôre very pro-police. I believe civilization needs a police force‚Äîalthough I don‚Äôt believe in policemen creating too many widows and orphans unnecessarily either. But we like the idea of a better policeman‚Äôs helmet. However, we took one look at it and said to the people who invented it, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre a rich corporation. We can‚Äôt afford to make a better policeman‚Äôs helmet. That‚Äôs just how the civilization works. All risks considered, it can‚Äôt work for us. But we want the civilization to have these. So we don‚Äôt maximize what we sell it for. Get somebody else to make it. Transfer the technology or whatever to somebody who can do it. But we‚Äôre not going to.‚Äù Thus, we didn‚Äôt try to disadvantage policemen from getting new helmets, but we decided not to manufacture helmets ourselves. There are businesses‚Äîgiven the way the civilization has developed‚Äîwhere being the only deep pocket around is bad business. In high school football, for example, a paraplegic or a quadriplegic will inevitably be created occasionally. And who with deep pockets can the injured person best sue other than the helmet manufacturer? Then everyone feels sorry, the injuries are horrible, and the case is dangerous for the manufacturer. I think big, rich corporations are seldom wise to make football helmets in the kind of a civilization we‚Äôre in. And maybe it should be harder to successfully sue helmet makers. I know two different doctors, each of whom had a sound marriage. When the malpractice premiums got high enough, they divorced their wives and transferred most of their property to their wives. And they continued to practice, only without malpractice insurance. They were angry at the civilization. They needed to adapt. And they trusted their wives. So that was that. And they‚Äôve not carried any malpractice insurance since. People adapt to a changing litigation climate. They have various ways of doing it. That‚Äôs how it‚Äôs always been and how it‚Äôs always going to be. What I personally hate most are systems that make fraud easy. Probably way more than half of all the chiropractic income in California comes from pure fraud. For example, I have a friend who had a little fender bender, an auto accident, in a tough neighborhood. And he got two chiropractors‚Äô cards and one lawyer‚Äôs card before he‚Äôd even left the intersection. They‚Äôre in the business of manufacturing claims that necks hurt. In California, I believe the Rand statistics showed that we have twice as many personal injuries per accident as in many other states. And we aren‚Äôt getting twice as much real injury per accident. So the other half of that is fraud. People just get so that they think everybody does it and it‚Äôs all right to do. I think it‚Äôs terrible to let that stuff creep in. If I were running the civilization, compensation for stress in workers‚Äô comp would be zero‚Äînot because there‚Äôs no work-caused stress, but because I think the net social damage of allowing stress to be compensated at all is worse than what would happen if a few people who had real work-caused stress injuries went uncompensated. I like the Navy system. If you‚Äôre a captain in the Navy and you‚Äôve been up for 24 hours straight and have to go to sleep, and you turn the ship over to a competent first mate in tough conditions and he takes the ship aground, clearly through no fault of yours, they don‚Äôt court-martial you, but your naval career is over. You can say, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs too tough. That‚Äôs not law school. That‚Äôs not due process.‚Äù Well, the Navy model is better in its context than would be the law school model. The Navy model really forces people to pay attention when conditions are tough, because they know that there‚Äôs no excuse. Napoleon46 said he liked luckier generals‚Äîhe wasn‚Äôt into supporting losers. Well, the Navy likes luckier captains. It doesn‚Äôt matter why your ship goes aground, your career is over. Nobody‚Äôs interested in your fault. It‚Äôs just a rule that we happen to have, for the good of all, all effects considered. I like some rules like that. I think that the civilization works better with some of these no-fault rules. But that stuff tends to be anathema around law schools: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not due process. You‚Äôre not really searching for justice.‚Äù Well, I am searching for justice when I argue for the Navy rule‚Äîfor the justice of fewer ships going aground. Considering the net benefit, I don‚Äôt care if one captain has some unfairness in his life. After all, it‚Äôs not like he‚Äôs being court-martialed. He just has to look for a new line of work. And he keeps vested pension rights and so on. So it‚Äôs not like it‚Äôs the end of the world. So I like things like that. However, I‚Äôm in a minority. I‚Äôd like to hear you talk a little bit more about judgment. In your talk, you said we should read the psychology textbooks and take the 15 or 16 principles that are best of the ones that make sense ‚Ä¶ The ones that are obviously important and obviously right. That‚Äôs correct. And then you stick in the ones that are obviously important and not in the books, and you‚Äôve got a system. Right. My problem seems to be the prior step, which is determining which ones are obviously right. And that seems to me to be the more essential question to ask. No, no. You overestimate the difficulty. Do you have difficulty understanding that people are heavily influenced by what other people think and what other people do, and that some of that happens on a subconscious level? No, I don‚Äôt. I understand that. Well, you can go right through the principles. And one after another, they‚Äôre like that. It‚Äôs not that hard. Do you have any difficulty with the idea that operant conditioning works‚Äîthat people will repeat what worked for them the last time? It just seems to me like there‚Äôs a lot of other things out there, as well, that also make a lot of sense. The system would quickly get too complicated, I imagine, as a result of too much cross talk. Well, if you‚Äôre like me, it‚Äôs kind of fun for it to be a little complicated. If you want it totally easy and totally laid out, maybe you should join some cult that claims to provide all the answers. I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs a good way to go. I think you‚Äôll just have to endure the world, as complicated as it is. Einstein has a marvelous statement on that: ‚ÄúEverything should be made as simple as possible, but no more simple.‚Äù I‚Äôm afraid that‚Äôs the way it is. If there are 20 factors and they interact some, you‚Äôll just have to learn to handle it, because that‚Äôs the way the world is. But you won‚Äôt find it that hard if you go at it Darwin-like, step-by-step, with curious persistence. You‚Äôll be amazed at how good you can get. You‚Äôve given us about three of the models that you use. I wondered where you found the other ones. And second, do you have an easier way for us to find them than going through a psychology textbook? I‚Äôm not averse to doing that, but it takes longer. There are a relatively small number of disciplines and a relatively small number of truly big ideas. And it‚Äôs a lot of fun to figure it out. Plus, if you figure it out and do the outlining yourself, the ideas will stick better than if you memorize ‚Äôem using somebody else‚Äôs cram list. Even better, the fun never stops. I was miseducated horribly, and I hadn‚Äôt bothered to pick up what‚Äôs called modern Darwinism.47 I do a lot of miscellaneous reading, too. But I just missed it. And in the last year, I suddenly realized I was a total damned fool and hadn‚Äôt picked it up properly. So I went back. And with the aid of [Richard] Dawkins‚ÄîOxford‚Äôs great biologist‚Äîand others, I picked it up. Well, it was an absolute circus for me in my 70s to get the modern Darwinian synthesis in my head. It‚Äôs so awesomely beautiful and so awesomely right. And it‚Äôs so simple once you get it. So one beauty of my approach is that the fun never stops. I suppose that it does stop eventually when you‚Äôre drooling in the convalescent home at the end. But at least it lasts a long time. If I were czar of a law school‚Äîalthough, of course, no law school will permit a czar; they don‚Äôt even want the dean to have much power‚ÄîI‚Äôd create a course that I‚Äôd call Remedial Worldly Wisdom that would, among other useful things, include a fair amount of properly taught psychology. And it might last three weeks or a month. I think you could create a course that was so interesting, with pithy examples and powerful examples and powerful principles, that it would be a total circus. And I think that it would make the whole law school experience work better. People raise their eyebrows at that idea. ‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt do that kind of thing.‚Äù They may not like the derision that‚Äôs implicit in the title Remedial Worldly Wisdom. But the title would be my way of announcing, ‚ÄúEverybody ought to know this.‚Äù And, if you call it remedial, isn‚Äôt that what you‚Äôre saying? ‚ÄúThis is really basic and everybody has to know it.‚Äù Such a course would be a perfect circus. The examples are so legion. I don‚Äôt see why people don‚Äôt do it. They may not do it mostly because they don‚Äôt want to. But also, maybe they don‚Äôt know how. And maybe they don‚Äôt know what it is. But the whole law school experience would be much more fun if the really basic ideas were integrated and pounded in with good examples for a month or so before you got into conventional law school material. I think the whole system of education would work better. But nobody has any interest in doing it. When law schools do reach out beyond traditional material, they often do it in what looks to me like a pretty dumb way. If you think psychology is badly taught in America, you should look at corporate finance. Modern portfolio theory? It‚Äôs demented! It‚Äôs truly amazing. I don‚Äôt know how these things happen. Hard science and engineering tend to be pretty reliably done. But the minute you get outside of those areas, a certain amount of inanity seems to creep into academia‚Äîeven academia involving people with very high IQs. But boy, what a school would be like that pounded a lot of the silliness out. But the right way to pound it out is not to have some 70-plus-year-old capitalist come in and tell seniors, ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs a little remedial worldly wisdom.‚Äù This is not the way to do it. On the other hand, a month at the start of law school that really pounded in the basic doctrines ‚Ä¶ Many of the legal doctrines are tied to other doctrines. They‚Äôre joined at the hip. And yet, they teach you those legal doctrines without pointing out how they‚Äôre tied to the other important doctrines. That‚Äôs insanity‚Äîabsolute insanity. Why do we have a rule that judges shouldn‚Äôt talk about legal issues that aren‚Äôt before them? In my day, they taught us the rule, but not in a way giving reasons tied to the guts of undergraduate courses. It‚Äôs crazy that people don‚Äôt have those reasons. The human mind is not constructed so that it works well without having reasons. You‚Äôve got to hang reality on a theoretical structure with reasons. That‚Äôs the way it hangs together in usable form so that you‚Äôre an effective thinker. And to teach doctrines either with no reasons or with poorly explained reasons? That‚Äôs wrong. Another reason why I like the idea of having a course on remedial worldly wisdom is that it would force more sense on the professors. It would be awkward for them to teach something that was contravened by lessons that were obviously correct and emphasized in a course named Remedial Worldly Wisdom. Professors doing so would really have to justify themselves. Is that a totally crazy idea? It may be crazy to expect it to be done. However, if somebody had done it, would you have found it useful? I think it would be a wonderful thing to have. Unfortunately, when it‚Äôs created, we won‚Äôt be here anymore. You‚Äôre proposing that this would be good to teach people in a course form so it would be accessible to them. Is there any way that it could be more accessible to us‚Äîother than having to ‚Ä¶ I get requests for pointers to easy learning all the time. I‚Äôm trying to provide a little easy learning today. But one talk like this is not the right way to do it. The right way to do it would be in a book. I hope what I‚Äôm saying will help you be more effective and better human beings. And if you don‚Äôt get rich, that won‚Äôt bother me. But I‚Äôm always asked this question: ‚ÄúSpoon-feed me what you know.‚Äù And, of course, what they‚Äôre often saying is ‚ÄúTeach me how to get rich with soft white hands faster. And not only let me get rich faster, but teach me faster, too.‚Äù I don‚Äôt have much interest in writing a book myself. Plus, it would be a lot of work for somebody like me to try and do it in my 70s. And I have plenty else to do in life. So I‚Äôm not going to do it. But it‚Äôs a screaming opportunity for somebody. I‚Äôd provide funds to support the writing of an appropriate book if I found someone with the wisdom and the will to do the job right. Let me turn to some of the probable reasons for present bad education. Part of the trouble is caused by the balkanization of academia. For instance, psychology is most powerful when combined with doctrines from other academic departments. But if your psychology professor doesn‚Äôt know the other doctrines, then he isn‚Äôt capable of doing the necessary integration. And how would anyone get to be a psychology professor in the first place if he were good with non-psychology doctrines and constantly worked non-psychology doctrines into his material? Such a would-be professor would usually offend his peers and superiors. There have been some fabulous psychology professors in the history of the world. [Robert] Cialdini of Arizona State was very useful to me, as was B. F. Skinner‚Äîfor his experimental results, if divorced from his monomania and utopianism. But averaged out, I don‚Äôt believe that psychology professors in America are people whose alternative career paths were in the toughest part of physics. And that may be one of the reasons why they don‚Äôt get it quite right. The schools of education, even at eminent universities, are pervaded by psychology. And they‚Äôre almost an intellectual disgrace. It‚Äôs not unheard of for academic departments, even at great institutions, to be quite deficient in important ways. And including a lot of material labeled as psychological is no cure-all. And given academic inertia, all academic deficiencies are very hard to fix. Do you know how they tried to fix psychology at the University of Chicago? Having tenured professors who were terrible, the president there actually abolished the entire psychology department. And Chicago, in due course, will probably bring back a new and different psychology department. Indeed, by now, it probably has. Perhaps conditions are now better. And I must admit that I admire a college president who will do something like that. I do not wish to imply in my criticism that the imperfections of academic psychology teaching are all attributable to some kind of human fault common only to such departments. Instead, the causes of many of the imperfections lie deep in the nature of things‚Äîin irritating peculiarities that can‚Äôt be removed from psychology. Let me demonstrate by a thought experiment involving a couple of questions. Are there not many fields that need a synthesizing super¬≠mind like that of James Clerk Maxwell but are destined never to attract one? And is academic psychology, by its nature, one of the most unfortunate of all the would-be attractors of super¬≠minds? I think the answers are yes and yes. One can see this by considering the case of any of the few members of each generation who can, as fast as fingers can move, accurately work through the problem sets in thermodynamics, electromagnetism, and physical chemistry. Such a person will be begged by some of the most eminent people alive to enter the upper reaches of hard science. Will such a super-gifted person instead choose academic psychology, wherein lie very awkward realities: a) that the tendencies demonstrated by social psychology paradoxically grow weaker as more people learn them, and b) that clinical (patient-treating) psychology has to deal with the awkward reality that happiness, physiologically measured, is often improved by believing things that are not true? The answer, I think, is plainly no. The super¬≠mind will be repelled by academic psychology, much as Nobel laureate physicist Max Planck48 was repelled by economics, wherein he saw problems that wouldn‚Äôt yield to his methods. We talk a lot about trade-offs between the quality of our life and our professional commitments. Is there time for a professional life, learning about these models, and doing whatever else interests you? Do you find time to do fun things besides learning? I‚Äôve always taken a fair amount of time to do what I really wanted to do, some of which was merely to fish or play bridge or play golf. Each of us must figure out his or her own lifestyle. You may want to work 70 hours a week for 10 years to make partner at Cravath and thereby obtain the obligation to do more of the same. Or you may say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not willing to pay that price.‚Äù Either way, it‚Äôs a totally personal decision that you have to make by your own lights. But whatever you decide, I think it‚Äôs a huge mistake not to absorb elementary worldly wisdom if you‚Äôre capable of doing it because it makes you better able to serve others, it makes you better able to serve yourself, and it makes life more fun. So if you have an aptitude for doing it, I think you‚Äôd be crazy not to. Your life will be enriched‚Äînot only financially, but in a host of other ways‚Äîif you do. Now, this has been a very peculiar talk for some businessman to come in and give at a law school‚Äîsome guy who‚Äôs never taken a course in psychology telling you that all of the psychology textbooks are wrong. This is very eccentric. But all I can tell you is that I‚Äôm sincere. There‚Äôs a lot of simple stuff that many of you are quite capable of learning. And your lives will work way better, too, if you do. Plus, learning it is a lot of fun. So I urge you to learn it. Are you, in effect, fulfilling your responsibility to share the wisdom that you‚Äôve acquired over the years? Sure. Look at Berkshire Hathaway. I call it the ultimate didactic enterprise. Warren‚Äôs never going to spend any money. He‚Äôs going to give it all back to society. He‚Äôs just building a platform so people will listen to his notions. Needless to say, they‚Äôre very good notions. And the platform‚Äôs not so bad either. But you could argue that Warren and I are academics in our own way. Most of what you‚Äôve said is very compelling. And your quest for knowledge and, therefore, command of the human condition and money are all laudable goals. I‚Äôm not sure the quest for money is so laudable. Well then, understandable. That I‚Äôll take. I don‚Äôt sneer, incidentally, at making sales calls or proofreading bond indentures. If you need the money, it‚Äôs fun earning it. And if you have to try a bunch of cases in the course of your career, you‚Äôll learn something doing that. You ought to do something to earn money. Many activities are dignified by the fact that you earn money. I understand your skepticism about overly ideological people. But is there an ideological component to what you do? Is there something that you‚Äôre irrationally passionate about? Yeah, I‚Äôm passionate about wisdom. I‚Äôm passionate about accuracy and some kinds of curiosity. Perhaps I have some streak of generosity in my nature and a desire to serve values that transcend my brief life. But maybe I‚Äôm just here to show off. Who knows? I believe in the discipline of mastering the best that other people have ever figured out. I don‚Äôt believe in just sitting down and trying to dream it all up yourself. Nobody‚Äôs that smart. Talk Three Revisited When I gave Talk Three in 1996, I argued that intense political animosity should be avoided because it causes much mental malfunction, even in brilliant brains. Since then, political animosity has increased greatly, both on the left and the right, with sad effects on the ability of people to recognize reality, exactly as I would have expected. Naturally, I don‚Äôt like this result. The grain of my emotional nature is to respond as Archimedes49 might respond if he complained now to God, ‚ÄúHow could you put in those Dark Ages after I published my formulas?‚Äù Or as Mark Twain once complained, ‚ÄúThese are sad days in literature. Homer is dead. Shakespeare is dead. And I myself am not feeling at all well.‚Äù Fortunately, I am still able to refrain from complaint in the mode of Mark Twain. After all, I never had more than a shred of an illusion that any views of mine would much change the world. Instead, I always knew that aiming low was the best path for me, so I merely sought 1) to learn from my betters a few practical mental tricks that would help me avoid some of the worst miscognitions common in my age cohort, and 2) to pass on my mental tricks only to a few people who could easily learn from me because they already almost knew what I was telling them. Having pretty well accomplished these very limited objectives, I see little reason to complain now about the un-wisdom of the world. Instead, what works best for me in coping with all disappointment is what I call the Jewish method: humor. As I revisit Talk Three in March 2006, I still like its emphasis on the desirability of making human systems as cheating-proof as is practicable, even if this leaves some human misery unfixed. After all, the people who rewarded cheating on a massive scale leave a trail of super-ruin in their wake, since the bad conduct spreads by example and is so very hard to reverse. And I fondly recall Talk Three‚Äôs emphasis on both the life-handling lessons I learned from my father‚Äôs friend, Grant McFayden, and one teaching method I learned from my father. I owe a lot to these long-dead predecessors, and if you like Poor Charlie‚Äôs Almanack, so do you

11. **Charlie's Insight 11**
   That gives us a big statistical advantage. Sometimes it comes from psychology, but often it comes from something else. And we only find a few, maybe one or two a year. We have no system for having automatic good judgment on all investment decisions that can be made. Ours is a totally different system. We just look for no-brainer decisions. As Buffett and I say over and over again, we don‚Äôt leap 7-foot fences. Instead, we look for 1-foot fences with big rewards on the other side. So we‚Äôve succeeded by making the world easy for ourselves, not by solving hard problems. Based on statistical analysis and insight? Well, certainly when we do make a decision, we think that we have an insight advantage. And it‚Äôs true that some of the insight is statistical in nature. However, again, we find only a few of those. It doesn‚Äôt help us merely for favorable odds to exist. They have to be in a place where we can recognize them. So it takes a mispriced opportunity that we‚Äôre smart enough to recognize. And that combination doesn‚Äôt occur often. But it doesn‚Äôt have to. If you wait for the big opportunity and have the courage and vigor to grasp it firmly when it arrives, how many do you need? For example, take the top 10 business investments Berkshire Hathaway‚Äôs ever made. We would be very rich if we‚Äôd never done anything else‚Äîin two lifetimes. So, once again, we don‚Äôt have any system for giving you perfect investment judgment on all subjects at all times. That would be ridiculous. I‚Äôm just trying to give you a method you can use to sift reality to obtain an occasional opportunity for rational reaction. If you take that method into something as competitive as common stock picking, you‚Äôre competing with many brilliant people. So even with our method, we only get a few opportunities. Fortunately, that happens to be enough. Have you been successful in creating an atmosphere where people below you can do the same things you‚Äôre talking about doing yourself? For example, you talked about the tendency toward commitment and consistency ‚Ä¶ Mostly about the terrible mistakes it causes you to make. How have you created an atmosphere comfortable enough for people to abandon that tendency and admit that they‚Äôve made a mistake? For example, someone here earlier this year from Intel talked about problems that occurred with their Pentium chip. One of the most difficult things for them to do was to realize they‚Äôd been going about it the wrong way and turn course. And it‚Äôs very difficult to do that in a complex structure. How do you foster that? Intel and its ilk create a coherent culture where teams solve difficult problems on the cutting edge of science. That‚Äôs radically different from Berkshire Hathaway. Berkshire is a holding company. We‚Äôve decentralized all the power, except for natural headquarters-type capital allocation. By and large, we‚Äôve chosen people we admire enormously to have the power beneath us. It‚Äôs easy for us to get along with them, on average, because we love and admire them. And they create the culture for whatever invention and reality recognition is going on in their businesses. And included in that reality recognition is the recognition that previous conclusions were incorrect. But we‚Äôre a totally different kind of company. It‚Äôs not at all clear to me that Warren or I would be that good at doing what Andy Grove42 does. We don‚Äôt have special competence in that field. We are fairly good at relating to brilliant people we love. But we have defects. For example, some regard me as absentminded and opinionated. I might be a mess at Intel. However, both Warren and I are very good at changing our prior conclusions. We work at developing that facility because without it, disaster often comes. Would you talk a little bit about your seeming predilection away from investing in high-technology stocks, on your own part and the part of Berkshire Hathaway? One of the things I‚Äôve found eye-opening and a little surprising is how the difficulties of running a low-tech business and those of running a high-tech business aren‚Äôt all that different. They‚Äôre all hard. But why should it be easy to get rich? In a competitive world, shouldn‚Äôt it be impossible for there to be an easy way for everybody to get rich? Of course they‚Äôre all hard. The reason we‚Äôre not in high-tech businesses is that we have a special lack of aptitude in that area. And yes‚Äîa low-tech business can be plenty hard. Just try to open a restaurant and make it succeed. You seem to be suggesting that there‚Äôs special aptitude required in high-tech businesses‚Äîthat they‚Äôre harder. But aren‚Äôt they equally difficult? The advantage of low-tech stuff for us is that we think we understand it fairly well. The other stuff we don‚Äôt. And we‚Äôd rather deal with what we understand. Why should we want to play a competitive game in a field where we have no advantage‚Äîmaybe a disadvantage‚Äîinstead of in a field where we have a clear advantage? Each of you will have to figure out where your talents lie. And you‚Äôll have to use your advantages. But if you try to succeed in what you‚Äôre worst at, you‚Äôre going to have a very lousy career. I can almost guarantee it. To do otherwise, you‚Äôd have to buy a winning lottery ticket or get very lucky somewhere else. Warren Buffett has said that the investment Berkshire made in an airline was a good example of what not to do. What chain of thinking led to that wrong decision? We were not buying stock in USAir on the theory that the common shareholders were certain to prosper, because the history of the airline business in terms of taking care of shareholders has been terrible. It was a preferred stock with a mandatory redemption. In effect, we were loaning money to USAir, and we had this equity kicker. We weren‚Äôt guessing whether it would be a great place for the shareholders. We were guessing whether it would remain prosperous enough to pay off a credit instrument, carrying a fixed dividend and a mandatory redemption. And we guessed that the business would not get so bad that we‚Äôd have a credit threat for which we were not being adequately compensated by the high rate we were getting. As it happened, USAir went right to the brink of going broke. It was hanging by a thread for several months. It‚Äôs since come back. And we‚Äôll probably get all our money back plus the whole coupon. But it was a mistake. [Editor‚Äôs note: Berkshire did indeed come out whole on its USAir investment.] I don‚Äôt want you to think we have any way of learning or behaving so you won‚Äôt make a lot of mistakes. I‚Äôm just saying that you can learn to make fewer mistakes than other people‚Äîand how to fix your mistakes faster when you do make them. But there‚Äôs no way that you can live an adequate life without making many mistakes. Part of what you must learn is how to handle mistakes and new facts that change the odds. Life, in part, is like a poker game, wherein you have to learn to quit sometimes when holding a much-loved hand. In fact, one trick in life is to get so you can handle mistakes. Failure to handle psychological denial is a common way for people to go broke. You‚Äôve made an enormous commitment to something. You‚Äôve poured effort and money in. And the more you put in, the more the whole consistency principle makes you think, ‚ÄúNow it has to work. If I put in just a little more, then it‚Äôll work.‚Äù And deprival-super¬≠reaction syndrome also comes in: You‚Äôre going to lose the whole thing if you don‚Äôt put in a little more. People go broke that way because they can‚Äôt stop, rethink, and say, ‚ÄúI can afford to write this one off and live to fight again. I don‚Äôt have to pursue this thing as an obsession, in a way that will break me.‚Äù Could you talk about the thoughts that went into your decision to swap your Capital Cities stock for Disney rather than taking cash? In the media, it was reported that you mentioned thinking about taking the cash. Disney‚Äôs a perfectly marvelous company, but it‚Äôs also very high-priced. Part of what it does is make ordinary movies, which is not a business that attracts me at all. However, part of what Disney has is better than a great gold mine. I mean, those videocassettes ‚Ä¶ Disney is an amazing example of autocatalysis.43 They had all those movies in the can. They owned the copyright. And just as Coke could prosper when refrigeration came, when the videocassette was invented, Disney didn‚Äôt have to invent anything or do anything except take the thing out of the can and stick it on the cassette. And every parent and grandparent wanted his descendants to sit around and watch that stuff at home on videocassette. So Disney got this enormous tailwind from life. And it was billions of dollars‚Äô worth of tailwind. Obviously, that‚Äôs a marvelous model if you can find it. You don‚Äôt have to invent anything. All you have to do is to sit there while the world carries you forward. Disney‚Äôs done a lot of new things right. Don‚Äôt misunderstand me. But a lot of what happened to Disney was like what a friend of mine said about an ignorant fraternity brother of his who succeeded in life: ‚ÄúHe was a duck sitting on a pond, and they raised the level of the pond.‚Äù Eisner and Wells were brilliant in how they ran Disney. But the huge tailwind from videocassette sales on all of the old stuff that was there when they came in‚Äîthat was just an automatic break for the new management. To be fair, they have been brilliant about creating new stuff, like Pocahontas and The Lion King, to catch the same tailwind. But by the time it‚Äôs done, The Lion King alone is going to do plural billions. And by the way, when I say ‚Äúwhen it‚Äôs done,‚Äù I mean 50 years from now or something. But plural billions‚Äîfrom one movie? Could you talk about why you left the law? I had a huge family. Nancy and I supported eight children. And I didn‚Äôt realize that the law was going to get as prosperous as it suddenly got. The big money came into law shortly after I left it. By 1962, I was mostly out, and I was totally out by 1965. So that was a long time ago. Also, I preferred making the decisions and gambling my own money. I usually thought I knew better than the client anyway. So why should I have to do it his way? So partly it was having an opinionated personality. And partly it was a desire to get resources permitting independence. Also, the bulk of my clients were terrific, but there were one or two I didn‚Äôt enjoy. Plus, I like the independence of a capitalist. And I‚Äôd always had sort of a gambling personality. I like figuring things out and making bets. So I simply did what came naturally. Do you ever gamble Las Vegas‚Äì¬≠style? I won‚Äôt bet $100 against house odds between now and the grave. I don‚Äôt do that. Why should I? I will gamble recreationally with my pals. And I‚Äôll occasionally play a much better bridge player, like Bob Hamman, who might be the best card player in the world. But I know I‚Äôm paying for the fun of playing with him. That‚Äôs recreational. As for gambling with simple mechanical house odds against me, why in the world would I ever want to do that, particularly given how I detest the manipulative culture of legalized gambling? I don‚Äôt like legalized gambling. And I‚Äôm not comfortable in Las Vegas, even though it does now include a higher percentage of wholesome family recreation. I don‚Äôt like to be with many of the types who hang around card parlors and so forth. On the other hand, I do like the manly art of wagering, so to speak. And I like light social gambling among friends. But I do not like the professional gambling milieu. Could you say something about how the mutual fund and money management business has changed since you got into it, and the growth of capital markets? Actually, I didn‚Äôt really get into it. I had a little private partnership for 14 years, up until a little over 20 years ago. However, I never had enough money from other people to amount to a hill of beans‚Äîat least by current investment management standards. So I‚Äôve never really been part of the mutual fund business. But the money management business has been one of the great growth businesses in the recent history of the United States. It‚Äôs created many affluent professionals and multi¬≠millionaires. But except for what might be called our own money, we‚Äôre really not in it. I was interested in the evolution of your investment strategy from when you first began using the Ben Graham model to the Berkshire Hathaway model. Would you recommend that model to a beginning investor‚Äîi.e., dumping most of it or all of it into one opportunity we think is a great one and leaving it there for decades? If losses are going to make you miserable‚Äîand some losses are inevitable‚Äîyou might be wise to utilize a very conservative pattern of investment and saving all your life. But in part, that‚Äôs because I‚Äôm good at taking losses. I can take ‚Äôem psychologically. And, besides, I have very few. The combination works fine. You and Buffett have said that Berkshire‚Äôs stock is overvalued and you wouldn‚Äôt recommend buying it. We didn‚Äôt say we thought it was overvalued. After all, today we‚Äôre in uncharted territory. I sometimes tell my friends, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing the best I can. But I‚Äôve never grown old before. I‚Äôm doing it for the first time, and I‚Äôm not sure that I‚Äôll do it right.‚Äù Warren and I have never been in this kind of territory‚Äîwith high valuations and a huge amount of capital. We‚Äôve never done it before. So we‚Äôre learning. Everything you and Buffett say seems logical. But it sounds like exactly the same language that Ben Graham was using 30 years ago when he was saying the stock market was overvalued, when it was at 900. By the way, I‚Äôm not promising that we will compound our present book value at 15 percent per annum. You talked about how important it was not to have an extreme ideology. What responsibility, if any, do you think the business and legal communities have for helping inner-city areas, spreading the wealth and so on? I‚Äôm all for fixing social problems. I‚Äôm all for being generous to the less fortunate. And I‚Äôm all for doing things where, based on a slight preponderance of the evidence, you guess that it‚Äôs likely to do more good than harm. What I‚Äôm against is being very confident and feeling that you know, for sure, that your particular intervention will do more good than harm, given that you‚Äôre dealing with highly complex systems wherein everything is interacting with everything else. So just make sure that what you‚Äôre doing ‚Ä¶ You can‚Äôt make sure. That‚Äôs my point. On the other hand, I did recently reverse the conclusions of two sets of engineers. How did I have enough confidence in such a complicated field to do that? Well, you might think, ‚ÄúOh, this guy is just an egomaniac who‚Äôs made some money and thinks he knows everything.‚Äù Well, I may be an egomaniac, but I don‚Äôt think I know everything. You must have the confidence to override people with more credentials than you whose cognition is impaired by incentive-caused bias or some similar psychological force that is obviously present. In effect, you‚Äôve got to know what you know and what you don‚Äôt know. What could possibly be more useful in life than that? You discussed Coke‚Äôs mistake. Do you have any thoughts about where Apple44 went wrong? Let me give you a very good answer‚Äîone I‚Äôm copying from Jack Welch, the CEO of General Electric. He has a PhD in engineering. He‚Äôs a star businessman. He‚Äôs a marvelous guy. And recently, in Warren‚Äôs presence, someone asked him, ‚ÄúJack, what did Apple do wrong?‚Äù His answer? ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have any special competence that would enable me to answer that question.‚Äù And I‚Äôll give you the very same answer. That‚Äôs not a field in which I‚Äôm capable of giving you any special insight. On the other hand, in copying Jack Welch, I am trying to teach you something. When you don‚Äôt know and you don‚Äôt have any special competence, don‚Äôt be afraid to say so. There‚Äôs another type of person I compare to an example from biology: When a bee finds nectar, it comes back and does a little dance that tells the rest of the hive, as a matter of genetic programming, which direction to go and how far. So about 40 or 50 years ago, some clever scientist stuck the nectar straight up. Well, the nectar‚Äôs never straight up in the ordinary life of a bee. The nectar‚Äôs out. So the bee finds the nectar and returns to the hive. But it doesn‚Äôt have the genetic programming to do a dance that says straight up. So what does it do? Well, if it were like Jack Welch, it would just sit there. But what it actually does is to dance this incoherent dance that gums things up. A lot of people are like that bee. They attempt to answer a question like that. And that is a huge mistake. Nobody expects you to know everything about everything. I try to get rid of people who always confidently answer questions about which they don‚Äôt have any real knowledge. To me, they‚Äôre like the bee dancing its incoherent dance. They‚Äôre just screwing up the hive. As someone who‚Äôs been in legal practice and business, how did you incorporate, or did you incorporate, these models into your legal practice? And how did it work? I suspect many of us have seen law firms that don‚Äôt appear to adhere to these kinds of models. Well, the models are there. But just as there are perverse incentives in academia, there are perverse incentives in law firms. In fact, in some respects, at the law firms, it‚Äôs much worse. Here‚Äôs another model from law practice: When I was very young, my father practiced law. One of his best friends, Grant McFayden, Omaha‚Äôs Pioneer Ford dealer, was a client. He was a perfectly marvelous man, a self-made Irishman who‚Äôd run away uneducated from a farm as a youth because his father beat him. So he made his own way in the world. He was a brilliant man of enormous charm and integrity‚Äîjust a wonderful, wonderful man. In contrast, my father had another client who was a blowhard, an overreaching, unfair, pompous, difficult man. And I must have been 14 years old or thereabouts when I asked, ‚ÄúDad, why do you do so much work for Mr. X, this overreaching blowhard, instead of working more for wonderful men like Grant McFayden?‚Äù My father said, ‚ÄúGrant McFayden treats his employees right, his customers right, and his problems right. And if he gets involved with a psychotic, he quickly walks over to where the psychotic is and works out an exit as fast as he can. Therefore, Grant McFayden doesn‚Äôt have enough remunerative law business to keep you in Coca-Cola. But Mr. X is a walking minefield of wonderful legal business.‚Äù This case demonstrates one of the troubles with practicing law. To a considerable extent, you‚Äôre going to be dealing with grossly defective people. They create an enormous amount of the remunerative law business. And even when your own client is a paragon of virtue, you‚Äôll often be dealing with gross defectives on the other side or even on the bench. That‚Äôs partly what drove me out of the profession. The rest was my own greed, but my success in serving greed partly allowed me to make easier the process of being honorable and sensible. Like Ben Franklin observed, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard for an empty sack to stand upright.‚Äù I‚Äôd argue that my father‚Äôs model when I asked him about the two clients was totally correct didaction. He taught me the right lesson. The lesson? As you go through life, sell your services once in a while to an unreasonable blowhard if that‚Äôs what you must do to feed your family. But run your own life like Grant McFayden. That was a great lesson. And he taught it in a very clever way‚Äîbecause instead of just pounding it in, he told it to me in a way that required a slight mental reach. I had to make the reach myself in order to get the idea that I should behave like Grant McFayden. And because I had to reach for it, he figured I‚Äôd hold it better. And, indeed, I‚Äôve held it all the way through until today, through all of these decades. That‚Äôs a very clever teaching method. There, again, we‚Äôre talking about elementary psychology. It‚Äôs elementary literature. Good literature makes the reader reach a little for understanding. Then it works better. You hold it better. It‚Äôs the commitment and consistency tendency. If you‚Äôve reached for it, the idea‚Äôs pounded in better. As a lawyer or executive, you‚Äôll want to teach somebody what my father taught me, or maybe you‚Äôll want to teach them something else. And you can use lessons like this. Isn‚Äôt that a great way to teach a child? My father used indirection on purpose. And look at how powerfully it worked‚Äîlike Captain Cook‚Äôs wise use of psychology. I‚Äôve been trying to imitate Grant McFayden ever since, for all my life. I may have had a few lapses. But at least I‚Äôve been trying. At the end of your article in OID, you mentioned that only a select few investment managers actually add value. Since you‚Äôre speaking to an audience of future lawyers, what would you encourage us to do in order to be able to add value in our profession? To the extent you become a person who thinks correctly, you can add great value. To the extent you‚Äôve learned it so well that you have enough confidence to intervene where it takes a little courage, you can add great value. And to the extent that you can prevent or stop some asininity that would otherwise destroy your firm, your client, or something that you care about, you can add great value. There are constructive tricks you can use. For example, one reason why my old classmate Joe Flom of Skadden, Arps has been such a successful lawyer is that he‚Äôs very good at dreaming up little vivid examples that serve to pound the point home in a way that really works. It‚Äôs enormously helpful when you‚Äôre serving clients or otherwise trying to persuade someone in a good cause to come up with a little humorous example. The ability to do that is a knack. So you could argue that the Joe Floms of the world are almost born with a gift. But he‚Äôs honed the gift. And to one degree or another, all of you were born with the gift, and you can hone it too. Occasionally, you get into borderline stuff. For instance, suppose you‚Äôve got a client who really wants to commit tax fraud.
